member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.RippleTransform.PerformActualCommand(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage,Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage,System.Drawing.Rectangle,Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.ImageResults@)
member.summary: PerformActualCommand does the actual work of the image processing command.
member.param: The source image for processing. This may be different from the original image.
The destination image. Dest will be null when InPlaceProcessing is true or when ConstructFinalImage returns null.

An area of the source image to process. When the destination image is non-null, it will always be the same size as imageArea. ImageArea only differs in size from the source image when the command is a subclass of ImageRegionCommand and when there is a region of interest.
The results object that will be used for this command.
member.returns: In most cases, PerformActualCommand should return null. When PerformActualCommand returns a non-null image, it is indicating that it has allocated a new image to use for the final image. This must be true if ConstructFinalImage returned null.

summary.para: This will rotate an image clockwise by the specified number of degrees.

remarks.para: This command will work with all except Pixel4bppIndexed. If a Pixel4bppIndexed image is passed to this command, it will attempt to convert the image to Pixel8bppIndexed image before rotating it.
Rotating images in 90 degree increments uses a very fast rotate algorithm.

member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of rotation in degrees.
member.value: The angle of rotation in degrees.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.RotateCommand.interpolation
member.summary: Gets or sets the of this command.
member.value: The used for rotation.

remarks.para: 1-bit images accept a value of None for fast rotation, and BiLinear or BiCubic for good but slower rotation.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.RotateCommand.VerifyProperties(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage)
member.summary: Verify the integrity of properties in the command before processing an image.
member.param: The image to be processed.
member.exception: Two byte per component images are limited to 90, 180 and 270 degree rotations.

remarks.para: This method does not check the integrity of the source image itself. That is already done by the time VerifyProperties is called.
Errors should be indicated by throwing an appropriate exception.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.RotateCommand.SelectPreferredPixelFormat(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage,Atalasoft.Imaging.PixelFormat,Atalasoft.Imaging.PixelFormat[])
member.summary: Chooses a pixel format that is preferred for this command.
member.param: The original source image.
The original image's pixel format.
An array of pixel formats supported by this command.
member.returns: A new pixel format to use for this command.

remarks.para: The default implementation returns the sourceFormat value.

In theory, a command should only ever return pixel format that it has direct support for. Unfortunately, many older commands advertised that they supported pixel formats that were not native to the command. To maintain compatibility with older versions of dotImage, this method allows a command to select a new pixel format for itself, without being bound to the ApplyToAnyPixelFormat property.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.RotateCommand.ConstructFinalImage(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage)
member.summary: Called by the default implementation of Apply, ConstructFinalImage constructs the image that will be used as the destination image for the command.
member.param: The source image being processed. This may be different from the source image passed into Apply.
member.returns: A new image for the result of the command, or null if it is not possible or necessary to make a destination image.

remarks.para: The default implementation returns a new image in the same pixel format as the source image.
The returned image must be the same size as the image passed in.

If it is not possible to allocate the image (for example, the pixel format is not know at this point), it is acceptable to return null. Returning null implies that the command will return a non-null image in PerformActualCommand.
If an error occurs, this method should throw an exception.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.RotateCommand.PerformActualCommand(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage,Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage,System.Drawing.Rectangle,Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.ImageResults@)
member.summary: PerformActualCommand does the actual work of the image processing command.
member.param: The source image for processing. This may be different from the original image.
The destination image. Dest will be null when InPlaceProcessing is true or when ConstructFinalImage returns null.

An area of the source image to process. When the destination image is non-null, it will always be the same size as imageArea. ImageArea only differs in size from the source image when the command is a subclass of ImageRegionCommand and when there is a region of interest.
The results object that will be used for this command.
member.returns: In most cases, PerformActualCommand should return null. When PerformActualCommand returns a non-null image, it is indicating that it has allocated a new image to use for the final image. This must be true if ConstructFinalImage returned null.
member.exception: Can't rotate two byte per pixel images in arbitrary increments.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.SkewCommand

summary.para: Using this command you can shift the top, bottom, left or right side of an image independently.

member.remarks: This command does not work with Pixel1bppIndexed or Pixel4bppIndexed . If an image with one of these formats is passed into this command, it will attempt to convert it to Pixel8bppGrayscale or Pixel8bppIndexed respectively.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.Transform

remarks.para: The default implementation returns the sourceFormat value.

In theory, a command should only ever return pixel format that it has direct support for. Unfortunately, many older commands advertised that they supported pixel formats that were not native to the command. To maintain compatibility with older versions of dotImage, this method allows a command to select a new pixel format for itself, without being bound to the ApplyToAnyPixelFormat property.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.TransformChainCommand

summary.para: This command allows you to combine multiple transforms into a single command call.

member.remarks: This method requires a continuous tone image. If the source image is not continuous, it will attempt to convert the image into one.

example.code:
' Load a 24-bit image. Dim image As AtalaImage = New AtalaImage("D:\Test Images\1.jpg")
' Create the TransformChainCommand and add a couple transforms to it. Dim cmd As TransformChainCommand = New TransformChainCommand() cmd.Add(New MarbleTransform(0.4, New Size(10, 10))) cmd.Add(New LensTransform(100,PoInteger.Empty))
' Apply the transform. Dim result As AtalaImage = cmd.Apply(image).Image image.Dispose()

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.UserTransformCallback
member.summary: Callback method for the UserTransform object.

example.para: This is a simple example of how you can create your own transforms.

param.name: callbackData
param.para: Contains the information used in the transform.

summary.para: This allows you to write your own transform methods and add them to the transform chain, just like the built-in transforms. To do this, you must supply a .

remarks.para: This method will be called once for each pixel in the output image. You need to set the FromPixel parameter to the pixels (may be fractional) that the input X and Y values will be pulled from. Again, you tell the transform processor where to pull the source pixel from.

Your callback method should be able to handle any kind of input range; inputs may be outside the image rectangle, if you are chaining transforms. Likewise, your function can output values that are outside the image rectangle. If your function is the last in the chain, values outside the image rect will be set to the background color.
This method requires a continuous tone image. If the source image is not continuous, it will attempt to convert the image into one.

example.code:
Private Sub menuUserTransform_Click(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) ' Load a 24-bit image. Dim image As AtalaImage = New AtalaImage("D:\Test Images\1.jpg")
' Apply the our own transform. Dim cmd As UserTransform = New UserTransform(New UserTransformCallback(UserCallback)) Dim result As AtalaImage = cmd.Apply(image).Image
' Display the result in a WorkspaceViewer. image.Dispose() Me.viewer.Image = result End Sub
Private Function UserCallback(ByVal Data As UserTransformData) As Boolean ' This will take small blocks from the image and rearrange them.
Dim fpx As Single = 0 Dim fpy As Single = 0 Dim stopPoints() As Single = New Single() {400, 360, 320, 280, 240, 200, 160, 120, 80, 40}
Dim xFound As Boolean = False Dim yFound As Boolean = False
Dim i As Integer For i = 0 To stopPoints.Length- 1 Step i + 1 If Not xFound Then If Data.CurrentPixel.X > stopPoints(i) Then fpx = stopPoints(i) + Data.CurrentPixel.X xFound = True Else fpx = Data.CurrentPixel.X End If End If
If Not yFound Then If Data.CurrentPixel.Y > stopPoints(i) Then fpy = stopPoints(i) + Data.CurrentPixel.Y yFound = True Else fpy = Data.CurrentPixel.Y End If End If
If xFound And yFound Then Exit For End If Next
Data.FromPixel = New PointF(fpx, fpy)
Return True End Function

The destination image. Dest will be null when InPlaceProcessing is true or when ConstructFinalImage returns null.

An area of the source image to process. When the destination image is non-null, it will always be the same size as imageArea. ImageArea only differs in size from the source image when the command is a subclass of ImageRegionCommand and when there is a region of interest.
The results object that will be used for this command.
member.returns: In most cases, PerformActualCommand should return null. When PerformActualCommand returns a non-null image, it is indicating that it has allocated a new image to use for the final image. This must be true if ConstructFinalImage returned null.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageProcessing.Transforms.WowTransform

summary.para: This transform creates an effect which is a bit like looking at the image though a clear sphere. If you set to true, the result looks as if you're inside the sphere.

member.remarks: This method requires a continuous tone image. If the source image is not continuous, it will attempt to convert the image into one.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.IImageReloader
member.summary: IImageReloader provides a mechanism to bring unloaded images back into memory. This interface is used by .
member.remarks: Typically, an IImageReloader is created at the same time that an image is first loaded into physical memory. That way the IImageReloader can encapsulate all the information needed to bring that image back into memory at a later time.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.IImageReloader.Reload
member.summary: Reload an image into memory.
member.returns: An representing a previously loaded image.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSource
member.summary: An abstract class that is used to define a flexible mechanism for managing large quantities of images without having to keep them all in memory at once.
member.remarks: ImageSource objects are configurable for memory usage or for aggressive unloading of images and can be built with a cache to allow transient data sources such as live video to be treated as if they were persistent.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSource.memoryInUse
member.summary: Returns an estimate of the number of bytes of memory currently in use by images in this ImageSource.
member.value: An integer representing an estimate of the number of bytes of memory currently in use by images in this ImageSource.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSource.memoryLimit
member.summary: This sets the limit for memory usage for this ImageSource. If memory usage goes beyond this, images will be dropped from memory until memory usage is below the limit.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSource.immediateUnload
member.summary: Determines if an image should be unloaded from memory immediately.
member.value: This is set to true by default. Even if this is set to true, it does not mean that the memory for an image will be immediately released, nor does it mean that garbage collection will happen.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSource.NotifyChangedImage(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage,Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage)
member.summary: This method is used to inform an ImageSource that one of its current acquired images has changed.
member.param: The original image acquired through one of Acquire methods.
An entirely new image that will replace the original image.
member.overloads: This method is used to inform an ImageSource that one of its current acquired images has changed.

remarks.para: If an ImageSource is used by several clients, it is useful to be able to have one client change an image and be able to notify any other client that a change has been made so that it can track the changes.
For example, if there are two open views on the same image, changes in one can be reflected in the other by calling NotifyChangedImage and by subscribing to the ChangedImage event.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.GetConnectionCallback,System.Boolean,System.Collections.IDictionary)
member.summary: Create an image accessor that uses IDbCommand objects to get images. The commands are created by sub-classes in the abstract methods.
member.param: A delegate that can be used to get a connection to the database. This delegate may be serialized, so it should be to a static method. In the case of ASP.NET, the deserialization can happen in another page or in another web-server instance.
True if the serialized state of the object will be encrypted. Please see documentation of sub-classes to see which members are encrypted.

The parameters that are passed to all of your stored procedures. For SqlCommands, the keys should be strings which are the names of the parameters and start with an @. For OleDbCommands, you must use a IDictionary with sorted keys (e.g. SortedList) and use index numbers (starting at 0) as keys. The parameters are added in the sort order of the keys.
The values can be any object that can be automatically converted by the IDbDataParameter for your connection. The extraParameters are not encrypted when this object is serialized. A copy of the the dictionary will be made upon construction, so that changes to it will not affect this object.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.EncryptSerializedState
member.summary: Whether or not the serialized state is encrypted. Please see documentation of sub-classes to see which members are encrypted.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.GetConnection
member.summary: A delegate that can return a connection to the database.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.Encryptor
member.summary: A delegate that can encrypt a string.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.Decryptor
member.summary: A delegate that can decrypt a string.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.ExtraParameters
member.summary: A copy of the extra parameters dictionary. This class does not support changing the parameters after the object has been constructed.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.ExtractImageStream(System.Int32)
member.summary: Extracts a stream from a row of the database.
member.returns: A stream representing the contents of the image

remarks.para: This function is implemented for DbImageSource to use.

The field can either be a blob, image or string. If it is a string, it is interpreted as a filename and the filestream is opened. In order to get a connection to the database, the getConnection callback will be called -- the connection returned doesn't have to be opened (it will be opened when necessary), but this function will definitely close it before it returns. This method will use the property to determine the column name of the image stream information. If that method returns null, it will assume that the information is in the first column.

member.param: The index of the stream in the source

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.CreateGetImageRowCommand(System.Data.IDbConnection,System.Int32)
member.summary: A method that can return a command that gets a single row dataset with the image stream information at the given index. The field can either be a varbinary, binary or image type (in which case the image stream is the value of the field) or it can be a string which will be interpreted as a filename that contains the image. The command should not be associated with a connection.
member.returns: A command that will a single row with the image stream information.
member.param: A connection to the database.
The index of the image stream.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.ImageFieldName
member.returns: The name of the image field in the dataset, or null if it's ok to assume it's in the first column.
member.summary: The name of the image field in the dataset returned by CreateGetImageRowCommand. If this method returns null, it is assumed to be in the first column.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.GetImageStreamCount
member.summary: Gets the number of image streams in this database. Each stream can contain more than one frame.
member.returns: The number of image stream in this database.
member.remarks: This function is implemented for DbImageSource to use.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.CreateGetImageStreamCountCommand(System.Data.IDbConnection)
member.summary: A command that can get the number of image streams in the source (each of which can contain multiple frames). This command should just return the number of streams (not the total frame count). The command should result in a single row dataset with the count in the first column. The command should not be associated with a connection.
member.returns: A command that can get the number of image streams in the source.
member.param: A connection to the database.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.GetFrameCountInImage(System.Int32,Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.DbImageSource.FrameCounter)
member.summary: The number of frames in the stream indicated by the imageStreamIndex
member.param: The index of the stream in the source. This is guaranteed to be in the range of: 0 < imageStreamIndex <= GetImageStreamCount()

A delegate that can count the number of frames in a stream, which you can use if you haven't stored the framecount elsewhere. To speed performance, it might be better to store the frame count in the data store and not use this delegate.
member.returns: The number of frames in the stream indicated by the imageStreamIndex
member.remarks: This function is implemented for DbImageSource to use.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbCommandImageAccessor.CreateGetFrameCountCommand(System.Data.IDbConnection,System.Int32)
member.summary: A command that returns the frame count for an image. If this method returns null, the frame count will be determined by decoding the image stream. If not null, this command should result in a single row dataset with the frame count in the first column. If the frame count is stored separately from the image stream, implementing this method can greatly increase performance (especially first access). This command should not be associated with any connection.
member.returns: A command that returns the frame count for an image.
member.param: A connection to the database.
The index of the image stream in the source.

member.summary: Creates a stream from the object obtained from the database. If the object is a byte array, it is attached to a MemoryStream. member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbSqlImageAccessor.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.GetConnectionCallback,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates an object that can be used with to access images stored in a database. The image streams are access by combining clauses of SQL Statements provided.
member.param: A delegate that can return connections to the database. This accessor must be able to be serialized, so make the delegate to a static method. If this accessor is used in an imagesoruce that is used in ASP.NET controls, then it will be serialized. This class creates SQL statements that use CTE from SQL Server, so the connection needs to be to a database that supports them.
True if the serialized state of the object will be encrypted. Please see documentation of sub-classes to see which members are encrypted.
The name of the image field in the data source (given by the ). Can be an expression, but then an "as" with a field name must appear at the end of it.
A comma separated list of the primary keys of the data source (given by the fromClause).
The source of the data rows. This would normally be a table name, but it can be anything that can appear in the from clause of a SQL Select statement. It should not contain "from" at the beginning.
member.overloads: Constructors for DbSqlImageAccessor

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbSqlImageAccessor.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.GetConnectionCallback,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates an object that can be used with to access images stored in a database. The image streams are access by combining clauses of SQL Statements provided.
member.param: A delegate that can return connections to the database. This accessor must be able to be serialized, so make the delegate to a static method. If this accessor is used in an imagesoruce that is used in ASP.NET controls, then it will be serialized. This class creates SQL statements that use CTE from SQL Server, so the connection needs to be to a database that supports them.
True if the serialized state of the object will be encrypted. Please see documentation of sub-classes to see which members are encrypted.
The name of the image field in the data source (given by the fromClause). Can be an expression, but then an "as" with a field name must appear at the end of it.
A comma separated list of the primary keys of the data source (given by the fromClause).
The source of the data rows. This would normally be a table name, but it can be anything that can appear in the from clause of a SQL Select statement. It should not contain "from" at the beginning.
A clause that can be used in a where clause of a SQL Select statement. It can be null, which means that you want all rows to be returned. It should not contain "where" at the beginning.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbSqlImageAccessor.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.GetConnectionCallback,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates an object that can be used with to access images stored in a database. The image streams are access by combining clauses of SQL Statements provided.
member.param: A delegate that can return connections to the database. This accessor must be able to be serialized, so make the delegate to a static method. If this accessor is used in an imagesoruce that is used in ASP.NET controls, then it will be serialized. This class creates SQL statements that use CTE from SQL Server, so the connection needs to be to a database that supports them.

The source of the data rows. This would normally be a table name, but it can be anything that can appear in the from clause of a SQL Select statement. It should not contain "from" at the beginning.
A clause that can be used in a where clause of a SQL Select statement. It can be null, which means that you want all rows to be returned. It should not contain "where" at the beginning.
A clause that can be used in an order by clause. If it is null, the data set is ordered by the primary keys. The dataset must have a defined order. It should not contain "order by" at the beginning.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbStoredProcImageAccessor.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.GetConnectionCallback,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.IDictionary)
member.summary: Construct an accessor that can access images in a database via stored procedures
member.param: A delegate that can return connections to the database. This accessor must be able to be serialized, so make the delegate to a static method. If this accessor is used in an imagesoruce that is used in ASP.NET controls, then it will be serialized.

Set to true if you want the serialized state of this accessor to be encrypted. You must set the Encryptor and Decryptor properties to handle the decryption and encryption. The extraParameters are not encrypted when serialized.

The name of a stored procedure that can get an image by index. It should take an int parameter called "@index" and any other parameters you need, and return the image stream at that index. index is not a primary key into your table, but instead is a number in range of 0 to count-1, where count is gotten by calling the stored procedure named in the getImageStreamCountProc argument. If you take any extra parameters (aside from the index), you should specify their values by using the extraParameters argument. The stored procedure should result in a single row dataset where the first column is the image. It can either be an encoded image in a varbinary or image field or a string. If it is a string it is interpreted as a filename, which will be opened to get to the images.

The name of a stored procedure that can get the number of image streams. There are no required parameters. The stored procedure should result in single row dataset with the count in the first column. If you need any extra parameters, you should specify their values by using the extraParameters argument.

The parameters that are passed to all of your stored procedures. For SqlCommands, the keys should be strings which are the names of the parameters and start with an @. For OleDbCommands, you must use a IDictionary with sorted keys (e.g. SortedList) and use index numbers (starting at 0) as keys. The parameters are added in the sort order of the keys.
The values can be any object that can be automatically converted by the IDbDataParameter for your connection. The extraParameters are not encrypted when this object is serialized. A copy of the the dictionary will be made upon construction, so that changes to it will not affect this object.
member.remarks:
Here are some sample stored procedures that would work to get images from an table called images, where the data was stored in an field called imageData.
Here is a stored procedure that would meet the specification for the getImageByIndexProc. @startId and @endId are extra parameters that would need to be passed in to the constructor.
create PROCEDURE GetImageByIndex @index int, @startId int, @endId int as set nocount on; with istr as ( select id, imagedata, row_number() over (order by id) as rn from images where id between @startid and @endid ) select imageData from istr where rn=(@index+1)
Here is a stored procedure that would meet the specification for the getImageStreamCountProc. @startId and @endId are extra parameters that would need to be passed in to the constructor.
create PROCEDURE GetImageStreamCount @startid int, @endid int as set nocount on; select count(*) from images where id between @startid and @endid
Note: the extra parameters must be the same for all stored procedures.
member.overloads: Constructors for DbStoredProcImageAccessor

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.DbStoredProcImageAccessor.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data.GetConnectionCallback,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.IDictionary)
member.summary: Construct an accessor that can access images in a database via stored procedures
member.param: A delegate that can return connections to the database. This accessor must be able to be serialized, so make the delegate to a static method. If this accessor is used in an imagesoruce that is used in ASP.NET controls, then it will be serialized.

Set to true if you want the serialized state of this accessor to be encrypted. You must set the Encryptor and Decryptor properties to handle the decryption and encryption. The extraParameters are not encrypted when serialized.

The name of a stored procedure that can get an image by index. It should take an int parameter called "@index" and any other parameters you need, and return the image stream at that index. @index is not a primary key into your table, but instead is a number in range of 0 to count-1, where count is gotten by calling the stored procedure named in the getImageStreamCountProc argument. If you take any extra parameters (aside from the index), you should specify their values by using the extraParameters argument. The stored procedure should result in a single row dataset where the first column is the image. It can either be an encoded image in a varbinary or image field or a string. If it is a string it is interpreted as a filename, which will be opened to get to the images.

The name of a stored procedure that can get the number of image streams. There are no required parameters. The stored procedure should result in single row dataset with the count in the first column. If you need any extra parameters, you should specify their values by using the extraParameters argument.

The name of a stored procedure that can get the frame count of an image stream by index. It should take an int parameter called "@index" and any other parameters you need, and return the frame count at that index. @index is not a primary key into your table, but instead is a number in range of 0 to count-1, where count is gotten by calling the stored procedure named in the getImageStreamCountProc argument. If you take any extra parameters (aside from the index), you should specify their values by using the extraParameters argument. The stored procedure should result in a single row dataset where the first column is the frame count. If you cannot provide this argument, you can pass null, and the frame count will be determined by decoding the image stream gotten with the getImageByIndexProc. Providing this argument can substantially speed up viewing of multi-framed images because viewers can know which images are visible without accessing the stream. A copy of the the dictionary will be made upon construction, so that changes to it will not affect this object.

The parameters that are passed to all of your stored procedures. For SqlCommands, the keys should be strings which are the names of the parameters and start with an @. For OleDbCommands, you must use a IDictionary with sorted keys (e.g. SortedList) and use index numbers (starting at 0) as keys. The parameters are added in the sort order of the keys.
The values can be any object that can be automatically converted by the IDbDataParameter for your connection. The extraParameters are not encrypted when this object is serialized. A copy of the the dictionary will be made upon construction, so that changes to it will not affect this object.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.DbImageSource
member.summary: A DbImageSource is a sub-class of ImageSource that allows you read-only access to images stored in a database.

example.code:
Imports System.Data Imports System.Data.SqlClient Imports System.Collections Imports Atalasoft.Imaging Imports Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources Imports Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.Data
Public Class DbImageSourceExample
' Gets a SQL Server specific connection to the image database Public Shared Function GetConn() As IDbConnection Return New SqlConnection("Data Source=DBServer;Integrated security=SSPI;Initial Catalog=ImageDatabase;") End Function
' create an accessor that uses SQL statements Public Function CreateSqlImageAccessor() As DbCommandImageAccessor Dim sqlParams As New Hashtable() sqlParams("@lower") = 2 sqlParams("@upper") = 4 Return New DbSqlImageAccessor(New GetConnectionCallback(AddressOf GetConn), False, "imageBlob", "id", "images", "id between 2 and 4", _ Nothing, Nothing, sqlParams) End Function
' get an image from the database Public Function GetImageFromDb(ByVal i As Integer) As AtalaImage Dim imgSrc As New DbImageSource(CreateSqlImageAccessor()) Return imgSrc(i) End Function
End Class

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.DbImageSource._dbAccessor
member.summary: The accessor used to get to the database. This class supports changing the accessor, but if you change anything about the connected accessor, you are responsible for calling Reset() on the image source.
member.value: The accessor used by this class to get images from the database.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.ImageSources.DbImageSource._doAllFrames
member.summary: Whether to include all of the frames as individual images in the source.
member.value: True if each frame is an image in the source. False if only the first frame is used. If DoAllFrames is false, this class doesn't ever decode images to find the frame count. So, if all of the images are known to be single-framed, this class will be much faster if this property is set to false.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.MarshalByRefCollectionBase.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns a reference to an IEnumerator interface, whose purpose is to grant access to an enumeration's items.
member.remarks: When GetEnumerator is called, it constructs an enumerator object containing the current version number in the collection and a reference to the collection's items. Every time the enumerator is accessed, it compares the version of the enumerator with the version of the collection. If the versions do not match, it means that the collection has changed; an exception then occurs.
member.returns: A reference to an IEnumerator interface.

member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to return the height of the image.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.LLGetRowStride
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to return the number of bytes necessary for a row of pixels. This number should be rounded up to the next multiple of 4 bytes.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.LLGetPixelAccessor
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to return a new PixelAccessor object suitable for their particular version of PixelMemory.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.LLClone
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to create a deep copy of the object.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.LLLock
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to lock the memory.
member.remarks: LLLock is called by Lock only when it is necessary to actually lock the memory. Lock manages both thread safety as well as accumulation of locks. For any number of calls to Lock without a call to Unlock, there will be precisely one call to LLLock. It is also guaranteed that LLLock can only be called by one thread at a time.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.LLUnlock
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to unlock the memory.
member.remarks: LLUnlock is called by Unlock only when it is necessary to actually unlock the memory. Unlock manages both thread safety as well as accumulation of locks. For any number of calls to Unlock, there will be precisely one call to LLUnlock when there are no further lock requests. It is also guaranteed that LLUnlock can only be called by one thread at a time.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.GetScanLinePtr(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a pointer to the specified scan line.
member.remarks: The PixelMemory must be locked before calling this method.
member.param: The index to the scan line. This value should be greater than or equal to 0 and less than the image height.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.ManagedPixelMemory.IsContiguous
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the memory is contiguous.
member.value: Returns true.
member.remarks: Presently, ManagedPixelMemory is contiguous, but this may change in the future.

member.remarks: AcquireScanline implies that data read will be written back to the image upon release. GetReadOnlyScanline does not require a release, thus the data will not ever be written back to the scanline.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelAccessor.MarshalCopy(System.IntPtr,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This exists only because when running managed code in the Sharepoint Sandbox if the method contains the call to Marshall.Copy() a security exception is thrown. So we pulled it out into its own method which passes the security check. In managed environment the code is never executed but the security exception was still being thrown.

member.summary: PixelMemory is an abstract class that defines how an image's pixels are represented in memory, how they are allocated, deallocated, and accessed.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory._lock
member.summary: Locks the pixel memory object.
member.remarks: In a sequence of calls to Lock, the memory will only actually be locked on the first call. Every call to Lock should be balanced with a call to Unlock. When the PixelMemory is disposed, all pending locks will be released. Client code is encouraged to use the object to make lock management easier.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.Lock
member.summary: Locks this instance of PixelMemory. For memory objects that are movable, this will prevent the PixelMemory from moving. Client code rarely needs to use this method.
member.exception: Attempt to lock PixelMemory during dispose.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.Unlock
member.remarks: In a sequence of calls to Unlock, the memory will only actually be unlocked when all locks have been released. Every call to Lock should be balanced with a call to Unlock. When the PixelMemory is disposed, all pending locks will be released. Client code is encouraged to use the object to make lock management easier.

member.summary: Indicates whether or not the PixelMemory is currently locked.

member.summary: Returns the number of bytes in a row of this image. The number is always rounded up to the next multiple of 4.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.LLGetHeight
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to return the height of the image.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.LLGetRowStride
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to return the number of bytes necessary for a row of pixels. This number should be rounded up to the next multiple of 4 bytes.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.LLGetPixelAccessor
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to return a new PixelAccessor object suitable for their particular version of PixelMemory.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.LLClone
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to create a deep copy of the object.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.LLLock
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to lock the memory.
member.remarks: LLLock is called by Lock only when it is necessary to actually lock the memory. Lock manages both thread safety as well as accumulation of locks. For any number of calls to Lock without a call to Unlock, there will be precisely one call to LLLock. It is also guaranteed that LLLock can only be called by one thread at a time.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory.LLUnlock
member.summary: Subclasses of PixelMemory implement this method to unlock the memory.
member.remarks: LLUnlock is called by Unlock only when it is necessary to actually unlock the memory. Unlock manages both thread safety as well as accumulation of locks. For any number of calls to Unlock, there will be precisely one call to LLUnlock when there are no further lock requests. It is also guaranteed that LLUnlock can only be called by one thread at a time.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory
member.summary: PixelMemoryFactory is a singleton object that is used for allocating all image memory in dotImage. The object is accessed through the static property.

example.code: PixelMemory memory = PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.Allocate(parameters);

member.remarks: All PixelMemory should be allocated through this object instead of constructing a concrete subclass of PixelMemory directly.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory._factory
member.summary: Gets the singleton object used for memory allocation.

example.code: PixelMemory memory = PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.Allocate(parameters);

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory.Factory
member.summary: Gets the singleton object used for memory allocation.

example.code: PixelMemory memory = PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.Allocate(parameters);

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory.Allocate(Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactoryParameters)
member.summary: Allocates a new PixelMemory object using the supplied parameters.
member.remarks: Allocate will use the Allocator property to perform the actual allocation. When the Allocator is invoked, it will be passed the AllocatorObject.

example.code: PixelMemory memory = PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.Allocate(parameters);

member.param: The parameters used to control how the PixelMemory object will be allocated.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory.Allocator
member.summary: Sets or gets the PixelMemoryAllocator that will be used to allocate PixelMemory.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to call the Allocator directly. Instead, use the Allocate method.

example.code: PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.Allocator = PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.DefaultAllocator;

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory.AllocatorObject
member.summary: Sets or gets and object passed to the Allocator delegate.
member.remarks: This is a memento object intended to be used by the Allocator to hold private data that might be needed at allocation time. This object is not currently used in the default allocator, although it may be used in the future. Client allocators should be prepared to handle conditions when this object might have been changed to something unexpected.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryFactory.DefaultAllocator
member.summary: Gets the default allocator that is used by dotImage.
member.remarks: The intent of this property is to allow client code to restore the allocator to "factory settings".

example.para: This example illustrates how to restore the Allocator to its default setting.
example.code: PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.Allocator = PixelMemoryFactory.Factory.DefaultAllocator;

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryLocker
member.summary: PixelMemoryLocker is a utility class to help manage the locking and unlocking of memory. By constructing a PixelMemoryLocker object in a using block, PixelMemory will be automatically locked on entrance and exit of the block.
member.remarks: PixelMemoryLocker should never be used outside of a using block. PixelMemoryLocker depends on Dispose being called in a predictable manner to operate correctly. Using a PixelMemoryLocker outside a using block will cause unpredictable behavior since the memory will be unlocked when the object is either disposed or garbage collected.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryLocker.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemory)
member.summary: Constructs an object that will automatically lock and unlock the supplied PixelMemory.
member.remarks: PixelMemoryLocker should never be used outside of a using block. PixelMemoryLocker depends on Dispose being called in a predictable manner to operate correctly. Using a PixelMemoryLocker outside a using block will cause unpredictable behavior since the memory will be unlocked when the object is either disposed or garbage collected.
member.param: The PixelMemory object to be locked. If mem is null, it will be ignored.
member.overloads: Constructs a new PixelMemoryLocker object.
member.remarks: Construction of the object will immediately lock the pixel memory.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Memory.PixelMemoryLocker.#ctor(Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaImage)
member.summary: Constructs an object that will automatically lock and unlock the PixelMemory for the supplied AtalaImage.
member.remarks: PixelMemoryLocker should never be used outside of a using block. PixelMemoryLocker depends on Dispose being called in a predictable manner to operate correctly. Using a PixelMemoryLocker outside a using block will cause unpredictable behavior since the memory will be unlocked when the object is either disposed or garbage collected.
member.param: An image to be locked. If image is null, PixelMemoryLocker will do nothing.

members.member:
This method is used to report an allocation of image memory.
MemoryAllocated will throw is the location has already been reported as allocated or if the location is null or the size is less than or equal to zero.
All memory reporting routines are thread-safe. /// A pointer to the first byte of image memory. The number of bytes used by this block of memory.

member.summary: This method is used to report when a block of allocated image memory has been reallocated.

remarks.para: If oldLocation has not been previously reported as allocated via MemoryAllocated, this method will throw.
This method is equivalent to:
ReportFreed(oldLocation);
ReportAllocated(newLocation, newSize);

member.param: The previous location in memory
The new location in memory
The size of the new block.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ComTextParser
member.summary: Parses COM Markers from a JPEG or PNG image into a collection of COM Text tags.

example.code: ComTextParser comParser = new ComTextParser(); ComTextCollection comTags = comParser.Parse("myimage.jpg");
Dim comParser As ComTextParser = New ComTextParser(); Dim comTags As ComTextCollection = comParser.Parse("myimage.jpg");

remarks.para: PNG and JPEG images support a type of metadata called COM Text. This is simple textual information that can be stored into an image. DotImage supports reading and writing this information to an image.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ComTextParser.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of ComTextParser.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ComTextParser.ParseFromImage(System.String)
member.summary: Parses COM Text data from an image file.
member.param: The image file to parse data from.
member.overloads: Parses COM Text data from an image file or stream.
member.returns: Returns a ComTextCollection containing all COM Text data.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ComTextParser.ParseFromImage(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Parses COM Text data from an image file stream.
member.returns: A ComTextCollection containing all COM Text tags.
member.param: The image file stream to parse data from.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ComTextParser.GetComTextData(Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ComTextCollection,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Reads the COM tags from a JPG or PNG stream.
member.param: A collection to receive the tags.
Stream containing the image data.
member.returns: True on success, false otherwise.

member.summary: Save the ComTextTags to the current image.

summary.para: TIFFTAG_COMPRESSION (259) UInt16

1 = COMPRESSION_NONE,
2 = COMPRESSION_CCITTRLE,
3 = COMPRESSION_CCITTFAX3,
4 = COMPRESSION_CCITTFAX4,
5 = COMPRESSION_LZW,
6 = COMPRESSION_OJPEG,
7 = COMPRESSION_JPEG,
32766 = COMPRESSION_NEXT (NeXT 2-bit RLE),
32771 = COMPRESSION_CCITTRLEW (#1 w/ word alignment),
32773 = COMPRESSION_PACKBITS (Macintosh RLE),
32809 = COMPRESSION_THUNDERSCAN (ThunderScan RLE)
TIFFTAG_PHOTOMETRIC (262) UInt16

0 = PHOTOMETRIC_MINISWHITE (min value is white),
1 = PHOTOMETRIC_MINISBLACK (min value is black),
2 = PHOTOMETRIC_RGB (RGB color model),
3 = PHOTOMETRIC_PALETTE (color map indexed),
4 = PHOTOMETRIC_MASK ($holdout mask),
5 = PHOTOMETRIC_SEPARATED (!color separations),
6 = PHOTOMETRIC_YCBCR (!CCIR 601),
7 = PHOTOMETRIC_CIELAB (!1976 CIE L*a*b*),
8 = PHOTOMETRIC_ICCLAB (ICC L*a*b* [Adobe TIFF Technote 4]),
9 = PHOTOMETRIC_ITULAB (ITU L*a*b*),
32844 = PHOTOMETRIC_LOGL (CIE Log2(L)),
32845 = PHOTOMETRIC_LOGLUV (CIE Log2(L) (u',v'))

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.JpegMarkerCopyFlags.CopyApp0

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection

summary.para: Contains a collection of EXIF tags.

member.remarks: See of to populate an ExifCollection with EXIF data from an image.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection.ThumbnailStream
member.summary: Gets or sets the thumbnail stream contained within this EXIF data.

remarks.para: EXIF information often contains a small thumbnail image. That image can be obtained from this property. The thumbnail can also be set or changed by setting this to a new stream.

Please note that saving a thumbnail inside a TIFF image requires that the thumbnail is a TIFF. When copying EXIF from a JPEG to a TIFF, ensure that the ThumbnailStream is converted from a JPEG to a TIFF.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection._makernoteHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets the makernote header.
member.remarks: This information is required to save EXIF with the original maker note data. It contains the header for vendor specific maker note tags identifying the type of makernote contained within this ExifCollection.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection.MakernoteHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets the makernote header.
member.remarks: This information is required to save EXIF with the original maker note data. It contains the header for vendor specific maker note tags identifying the type of makernote contained within this ExifCollection.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the ExifCollection class.
member.overloads: Create a new instance of .

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection.ToByteArray
member.summary: Creates a byte array of the EXIF data that can be inserted into an image.
member.remarks: This method is intended on being used to store EXIF in a Jpeg Image. To add or edit EXIF data in a JPEG image, create a JPEG APP1 Marker from this data. See for more information.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the ExifTag by index in the collection and allows the EXIF tags to be enumerated.
member.value: The EXIF Tag by index in the collection.
member.param: The zero based index in the collection.

member.summary: Copies items from this collection into an array.
member.param: An array of ExifTags to hold the items.
An index in the array where the data will be copied.

member.summary: Adds a new ExifTag to this collection.

member.summary: Remove a specified ExifTag from the collection.
member.param: The tag to remove

member.returns: Returns -1 if the tag was not found.
member.param: The specific tag to search for.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifCollection.LookupTag(Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifTagID,Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifTagIfd)

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifParser
member.summary: Parses EXIF data from JPEG or TIFF images into a collection of EXIF tags.

remarks.para: EXIF (Exchangeable Image File Format) is a standard for storing interchange information in image files, in particular JPEG images. This metadata is commonly used in digital camera images to store information specific to digital photography such as shutter speed, date taken, aperture, GPS information, and other information depending on the make of the camera.

example.para: This example demonstrates how to retreive EXIF tags from a JPEG image.
example.code: ExifTextParser exifParser = new ExifTextParser(); ExifTextCollection exifTags = exifParser.Parse("myimage.jpg");
Dim exifParser As ExifTextParser = New ExifTextParser() Dim exifTags As ExifTextCollection = exifParser.Parse("myimage.jpg")
example.para: This example shows how to retrieve EXIF data from an image, then save it back to a new image.
example.code: 'get EXIF Tags Dim exifParse As ExifParser = New ExifParser() Dim exifTags As ExifCollection = exifParse.ParseFromImage("c\in.jpg") 'get JPEG Markers Dim appMarkersIn As JpegMarkerCollection = New JpegMarkerCollection("c:\in.jpg") 'read image Dim myWorkspace As Workspace = New Workspace() myWorkspace.Open("c:\in.jpg") 'get the DataTime Tag from the image and display the value If Not exifTags Is Nothing Then Dim tag As ExifTag = exifTags.LookupTag("DateTime") If Not tag Is Nothing Then MessageBox.Show("This photo was taken on " & tag.Data.ToString()) End If End If Dim jpeg As JpegEncoder = New JpegEncoder(75) 'only write EXIF Tags back to the image (APP1) Dim appMarkersOut As JpegMarkerCollection = New JpegMarkerCollection() Dim mk As JpegMarker For Each mk In appMarkersIn If mk.Type = JpegMarkerTypes.MarkerApp1 Then appMarkersOut.Add(mk) End If Next jpeg.AppMarkers = appMarkersOut myWorkspace.Save("c:\out.jpg", jpeg)

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifParser.ParseFromByteArray(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Parses a byte array of EXIF data.
member.returns: An holding a list of all the EXIF values that were read. This list will be empty if no values were read.
member.remarks: Use this method for dealing with raw image data. For reading Exif from an image, use .

example.para: This example shows how to obtain the Exif data array directly from the raw data of a Jpeg.
example.code:
Dim exifParse As ExifParser = New ExifParser Dim exif As ExifCollection Dim fs As FileStream = New FileStream("C:\testImage.jpg", FileMode.Open, FileAccess.Read, FileShare.Read)
fs.Seek(0, SeekOrigin.Begin) Dim markers As JpegMarkerCollection = New JpegMarkerCollection(fs) Dim exifMarker As JpegMarker = markers.LookupMarker(JpegMarkerTypes.MarkerApp1) Dim exifBytes(exifMarker.Data.Length) As Byte exifBytes = exifMarker.Data
exif = exifParse.ParseFromByteArray(exifBytes)

member.param: An array containing the entire EXIF string to parse.

member.name: E:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifParser.CodecError
member.summary: This event is used by the ExifParser object to report errors that occur when parsing an image.
member.remarks: The DotImage EXIF Parser is aggressive in suppressing errors encountered while parsing damaged or somewhat malformed files. Normally these errors are not reported. This event provides a mechanism for an application to record, report, or abort in the event of an error.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.ExifTag.Data
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of this EXIF tag.
member.value: The value of this EXIF tag.

remarks.para: The returned value is a variant object that is stored at its native type. Use to view the string data of this tag.
When editing or adding EXIF data, this tag must be able to be translated to the appropriate Type as defined in the ExifTag.Type property.
Array of types is also supported. To determine if a tag is an array of values ihe invoke the GetType().IsArray() of the Data object.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.IptcParser

remarks.para: The Newspaper Association of America (NAA) and the International Press Telecommunications Council (IPTC) have worked jointly to design a model to store all sorts of data in an image. This metadata is commonly known as IPTC. Adobe Photoshop uses IPTC to store information in images as well as much of the newspaper and press industry. DotImage can read and write IPTC information to a JPEG image and read IPTC information from a TIFF image.
IPTC data can be modified and saved back in a JPEG or TIFF image.
For more information on IPTC and Metadata in general see %iptc.html% and %metadataoverview.html%.

member.summary: Parses IPTC data from JPEG or TIFF images into a collection of IPTC tags.

example.code: IptcTextParser iptcParser = new IptcTextParser(); IptcTextCollection iptcTags = iptcParser.Parse("myimage.jpg");
Dim iptcParser As IptcTextParser = New IptcTextParser() Dim iptcTags As IptcTextCollection = iptcParser.Parse("myimage.jpg")

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of IptcParser.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.IptcParser.ParseFromByteArray(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Parses IPTC data from a byte array.
member.returns: An IptcCollection containing the parsed data.
member.remarks: This is useful if the image format stores the IPTC in a different location within the file. For instance, IPTC may be stored in the TIFFTAG_RICHTIFFIPTC (ID 33723) instead of the Adobe Photoshop tag.
member.param: A byte array containing the IPTC data.

The zero based frame index of a multipage TIFF image to load data from.
member.overloads: Parses IPTC data from a JPEG or TIFF image file or stream.

member.remarks: A Jpeg Marker is a data block stored in Jpeg images. Also known as JPEG APPn markers. There are 14 markers that can be stored in JPEG images. See for retreiving this data from existing JPEG images.

member.name: M:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.JpegMarker.Dispose
member.summary: Call this method to free the JpegMarker data from memory without waiting for the Garbage Collector.

remarks.para: Metadata such as EXIF, IPTC, and COM Markers are stored in as Jpeg Markers in JPEG files. This class allows Jpeg markers to be accessed and resaved in a new image (both lossy or lossless).
The marker data returned does not contain the first four bytes of actual marker data. These four bytes contain the length of the data and the marker type.

summary.para: Contains a collection of JpegMarkers and methods to access JpegMarker data.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.PhotoshopResourceParser
member.summary: Parses Photoshop resources from JPEG, TIFF, and PSD images into a collection of PhotoshopResources.
member.remarks: The Format Specification for Photoshop Resources is available to purchase from Adobe. This document contains information for each resource ID. The data in each is stored as a byte array. The developer must know the format of each ID, available in the specification, to parse to the respective value (string, integer, raw bytes, etc).
member.example: Extract DPI information from a PSD File

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.TiffTag
member.summary: Holds the data of a single TIFF Tag.

remarks.para: TIFF Tags are returned when obtaining tags with the TiffDecoder.GetTiffTag method in TiffDecoder, and set with the property in the TiffEncoder.
An alternative, and more comprehensive interface for retrieval and editing of TIFF Tags is the TiffFile class.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.TiffTag._id
member.summary: Gets the ID of this TIFF tag.
member.value: The ID of this TIFF tag.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.TiffTag._data
member.summary: Gets or sets the data of a specific TIFF tag.
member.value: The data of this TIFF tag.

remarks.para: TIFF Tag data can is stored in the type which it was read from a file.

The TIFF Tag Data can contain an offset value which is a reference pointer to a location in the TIFF File with the actual image data. In this case the property is true and the actual data can be obtained by invoking the LoadReferenceTagData in the TiffDirectory class.
The TIFF Tag Data can be an array of values of the appropriate type. To test if the Data contains an array invoke the GetType().IsArray() method.

member.exception: Thrown when the conversion from the data passed in to the actual type causes an overflow.
Thrown when the an attempt was made to convert the data to the appropriate type, but failed.
Thrown when the data passed is not the correct type.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.TiffTag._type
member.summary: Gets the TIFF DataType for this TIFF Tag.
member.value: The TIFF DataType for this TIFF Tag.
member.remarks: Each TIFF Tag has a specific data type. When the TIFF Tag is created with the TiffTagID enumeration parameter, this value is automatically determined based on the standard TIFF Tag ID.

summary.para: Contains a collection of TIFF tags, used tor writing TIFF Tags to an image when saving.

remarks.para: All TIFF images contain metadata explaining the size, colordepth, strip size, and other detailed information of the image. A TIFF tag is identified by an ID. DotImage can read this information from a TIFF file as a string.
For more information, see the section on Tiff Tags and the Metadata Overview.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.Metadata.XmpParser
member.summary: The XmpParser class can extract XMP Binary data from an image, and parse it into XML content.

remarks.para: There are two important methods in this class. returns a byte array of the raw XMP data. It is used in the DotImage Annotations Toolkit, to load XMP annotations data. returns an XmlDocument that can be easily parsed using features in the .NET XML namespace.
For more information on XMP including the specification, visit http://www.adobe.com/products/xmp/.

example.code: XmpParser xmpParser = new XmpParser(); XmlDocument doc = xmpParser.Parse("document.tif", 1);
Dim xmpParser As XmpParser = New XmpParser() Dim doc As XmlDocument = xmpParser.Parse("document.tif", 1)

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.AtalaPixelFormatChanger
member.summary: This is the standard PixelFormat changer class.

remarks.para: The AtalaPixelFormatChanger does standard conversion between all differing pixel formats. Note that when converting from a pixel format that represents a large amount of data to a pixel format that represents a lesser amount of data, information will be lost. Therefore, it is not possible to perform an accurate round trip conversion.
When converting to a palette image (8-bit indexed or less) this will use Floyd Steinberg Dithering. See DocumentPixelFormatChanger for converting document images.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.ProcessQueue
member.summary: Holds a collection of that are awaiting asynchronous processing.
member.remarks: When the is runing in asynchronous mode all image processing calls through the Workspace.ProcessImage method or the read and save methods will put the process into this queue. The purpose is to process images sequentially and prevent threading issues. Each workspace object can process only one image at a time, but as long as Workspace.IsAsynchronous is true, the processing will be performed in a separate thread.

member.name: T:Atalasoft.Imaging.SerializationHelper
member.remarks:
In the current .NET model, one must ask for a field within a serialization object acting under the assumption that it will be there. If the field isn't there, an Exception is thrown. An object is deserializable if and only if all fields of an object have been serialized.
In the dotImage model, an object is constructed with default values which are then replaced by the information in the SerializationInfo object. In dotImage this makes more sense since several objects' underlying data is optional or mutually exclusive.
To retrieve a scalar, pass GetValue() the SerializationInfo object, the name of the field, and a reference to the variable that will hold the value. GetValue() will return true if it performed an assignment to the variable.
To retrieve a non-scalar type, pass GetValue() the SerializationInfo object, the name of the field and its expected Type. GetValue will return the object if it found it, null otherwise.
member.summary: SerializationHelper is a set of static methods to help in the process of deserialization of an object graph.

member.summary: Get a value from a SerializationInfo object
member.param: The object in which to look for the value.
The name of the value.
The place to store the retrieved value.
member.returns: true if the value was found, false otherwise.
member.overloads: Get a value from a SerializationInfo object.

summary.para: The UndoCollection class is used to manage operations that need undo/redo functinality. The collection contains properties to specify the number of allowed operations to undo or redo.

para.EM: NOTE: The UndoCollection class is intended for use in the
class only, and should not be used on its own. The UndoCollection relies on the Workspace's
in order to save the current images.

remarks.para: The undo collection may be used to create an Undo/Redo menu in your project. The Add method should be called at the point you want to save as the 'undo point' (for examble, BEFORE an ImageCommand is applied). To undo or redo an operation, simply call the or methods. You can access the property to determine what the next undo or redo will accomplish. The following code example shows how this is done.

example.para: Accessing the description of the next operation to undo/redo.
example.code: Dim Viewer As WorkspaceViewer ... Dim undoDescription As String = Viewer.Undos(Viewer.Undos.Count - Viewer.Undos.NumUndos).Description Dim redoDescription As String = Viewer.Undos(Viewer.Undos.Count - Viewer.Undos.NumUndos - 1).Description

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.UndoCollection.levels
member.summary: Gets or set the number of Undo levels in this collection.

remarks.para: The Levels property limits the number of undo's or redo's that are saved. For example, to limit the Workspace to only be able to undo a single operation, set the Levels property to 1.

summary.para: The workspace object is the container that is used to manage changes to images and provide an interface to open, save, and manipulate images either synchronously or asynchronously.

example.para: This example demonstrates how to create a new workspace, open an image, resample it, then save it to a file.
example.code: Dim myWorkspace As Workspace = New Workspace() myWorkspace.Open("image.png") myWorkspace.ApplyCommand(New ResampleCommand(myWorkspace.Width / 2, myWorkspace.Height / 2)) myWorkspace.Save("newImage.png", New PngEncoder()) myWorkspace.Dispose()

remarks.para: The Workspace object, part of the Atalasoft.Imaging namespace, provides a container that allows for intuitive image processing and management of AtalaImage and ImageCollection objects. The Workspace can be used to manage changes to AtalaImage objects and access methods to open, save, and manipulate images.

Many image processing functions may create new AtalaImage objects. The Workspace manages the creation of these objects by keeping a single current image and providing events when the image changes. The Workspace also disposes of old images when they are no longer needed. You can access the current AtalaImage with the Image property of the Workspace object.
The Workspace is designed to operate either synchronously or asynchronously for multi-threading operations. This behavior is set by the property.
See the WinForm's WorkspaceViewer for a Workspace object with a user interface for displaying images.

member.name: F:Atalasoft.Imaging.Workspace.autoDispose
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the Workspace should dispose all images it contains when finalized.
member.value: A value indicating if the Workspace should dispose all images it contains when finalized.
member.remarks: This value is true by default. Setting this value to false is useful when using an Images from another location. This only prevents images from being disposed when the associated Workspace object is disposed or finalized. To prevent images from being disposed when processing, handle the event and set the cancel property in the event args to true. Also consider using instead of the property when setting a new image.

member.summary: Fires when an error occurs in a separate thread when being processed asynchronously.
member.remarks: This event can be handled to react to an exception when it occurs in another thread. Typically a message box with exception details is displayed to the user. When this event is not handled, and the Asynchronous property is true, errors can go un-noticed, and without any error messages displayed.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if method calls through this Workspace object are processed asynchronously in a background thread.

remarks.para: By default, this value is false. When this value is true the workspace is operating in asynchronous mode and the is used to queue each command that is applied to the image. If the is accessed directly, unexpected threading issues might occur.

member.name: P:Atalasoft.Imaging.Workspace.Image
member.summary: Gets or sets the current that is active in this Workspace.

remarks.para: When the image that is being set already exists in the ImageCollection, then that image is set as the current, and the ChangedImage event fires. When the image being set does not exist in the collection, the current image is replaced with the new image, and the current image is either added to the , or disposed.

To replace the current image, without disposing it, or placing it into the UndoCollection, use the method in the by calling myWorkspace.Images.Replace(newImage) instead of myWorkspace.Image = newImage.
